message.content:
cs.CR, cs.PL, cs.SE, cs.DC, cs.DS

The paper discusses a new specification language for writing machine-checkable descriptions of SOAP-based security protocols and their properties. This falls under the category of computer security (cs.CR) as it deals with security protocols. The language is based on the pi calculus, which is a process calculus used for describing concurrent systems, and XML syntax, which is used for expressing SOAP messaging. This suggests that the paper may also fall under the categories of programming languages (cs.PL) and software engineering (cs.SE). The implementation of the language involves compiling it into the applied pi calculus and using a protocol verifier, which suggests that the paper may also fall under the categories of distributed, parallel, and cluster computing (cs.DC) and data structures and algorithms (cs.DS).
